user_input: Could you please explain what module information I need to know regarding compulsory, optional, and elective modules for my degree programme?
response:
You need to know which modules are compulsory vs optional/elective, the credit rules and any prerequisites/mutual exclusions, and ensure your choices fit the timetable. 
- Review your programme diet to see compulsory modules and the permitted groups/credits for optional and elective choices. 
- Use the UCL Module Catalogue to read each module’s syllabus (content, learning outcomes, assessments) and check any prerequisites or entry tests. 
- For combinations, load balancing, or specialism advice, contact your Programme Director or Academic Year Coordinator (you may also discuss with your Personal Tutor). 
- If selecting modules from other departments, first seek permission from your Programme Director; they may direct you to the Module Leader. 
- Check for timetable clashes and balance credits across terms; for administrative issues with selection/confirmation, contact your Programme Administrator. 
Warnings: Some programmes have no optional/elective modules; modules may be grouped with rules or be mutually exclusive; you must not pick options that clash; if you previously passed a module that is now compulsory, discuss with your Programme Director in advance. 
Source: Module information & selection – Modules; Module information; Key contacts for module selection; Module availability
retrieved_contexts:
Module information & selection  
Advice on choosing options and electives, general information on choosing modules, and key contacts for module selection.  
Modules  
Modules are the individual units of study which lead to the award of credit (usually 15 or 30 credits for taught modules, 30 credits for undergraduate dissertations/ final projects, 60 credits for postgraduate taught dissertations, and 105 credits for postgraduate research dissertations.) Each degree programme has a programme diet that defines the set of modules that must be taken (referred to compulsory or core), and, in some cases, that may optionally be taken (referred to as optional or elective.)  
Compulsory modules are essential to a programme's core curriculum; optional modules are usually closely related to the programme's core discipline and provide students with an opportunity to specialise in specialist/ complimentary subject areas; elective modules are usually less closely related to the core discipline, but allow students the opportunity to explore their interests more widely.  
Some programmes or years of study do not include optional or elective modules, with all modules being compulsory. Where programmes do include optional or elective choices, these are usually organised into groups which have rules set to define how many credits must or may be taken, whether any selections must be taken in combination or are mutually exclusive, and whether modules have pre-requisite conditions or entry tests.  
Module availability  
Modules for Computer Science students

Students who have previously passed a module that is compulsory during a subsequent period of study (for example, if they took a module as an option on a BSc that is then compulsory on an MSc), then they must discuss this with their Programme Director in advance of module selection and agree a course of action.  
Section 2: Module Selection | UCL Academic Manual  
Section 2: Module Selection - Overlapping Content | UCL Academic Manual  
Module information  
Information about module syllabuses (i.e. their content, learning outcomes, and assessments) and timetabling of synchronous activity.  
A module's syllabus is a summary description of its academic content and how students' learning will be assessed. The syllabus may also include indicative learning outcomes, which describe what skills and knowledge students should be able to demonstrate on successful completion of the module. Students should review the syllabuses for their modules to help them make any optional and elective choices and to help contextualise their learning experience.  
Module catalogue  
Students can access current module syllabuses via the UCL Module Catalogue, which is a comprehensive directory of all modules across the whole of UCL, published in a consistent, searchable and accessible format. The content of syllabuses will vary across departments, but the catalogue aims to give students enough detail to make an informed decision about their module selections. Some Computer Science modules have published module introduction videos to help inform module selection.

Academic advice on specific modules  
For advice about a specific module, for example relating to its syllabus, learning outcomes, prerequisite conditions, or self-assessment of suitability, students should contact the Module Leader or general contact, whose contact details are set out in the UCL Module Catalogue.  
Administrative advice and troubleshooting  
If a student experiences any issues with making or confirming their module selections, they should contact their Programme Administrator.

Programme timetables have been designed such that synchronous sessions for compulsory modules will not clash. Sessions for some optional and elective modules on a programme may clash (due to the number of modules we offer and the finite timetabling options available), and therefore not all combinations of modules will be possible. Students must not select optional or elective modules whose sessions clash with those of their compulsory modules or with each other.  
Students selecting optional or elective modules should carefully consider the timetable that eventuates from their module selections in terms of workload and clustering, i.e. the balance of credits across the two teaching terms and the pattern of synchronous events in each week.  
Key contacts for module selection  
Contacts for approval of module selection and for any issues that arise.  
Academic advice on module selection  
For academic advice on module selection, for example relating to taking particular combinations of modules, load balancing, or suitability for future specialism, students should contact their Programme Director or Academic Year Coordinator in the first instance. Students may also discuss their selection decisions with their Personal Tutor.  
Students intending to select modules from other departments, must seek the permission of their Programme Director in the first instance, who will advise on whether this is allowed and whether they must also seek the permission of the relevant Module Leader in the module's home department.  
Academic advice on specific modules
reference: Module information includes details about compulsory, optional, and elective modules within a degree programme. Compulsory modules are essential to the programme's core curriculum and must be taken. Optional modules are closely related to the core discipline and allow students to specialise in specialist or complementary subject areas. Elective modules are usually less closely related to the core discipline and provide an opportunity to explore interests more widely. Some programmes or years of study may not include optional or elective modules, with all modules being compulsory. Where optional or elective choices exist, they are organised into groups with rules defining how many credits must or may be taken, whether selections must be combined or are mutually exclusive, and whether modules have pre-requisite conditions or entry tests.

user_input: What is the process and deadline for module registration for new undergraduate students at UCL?
response:
Register your Term 1 and 2 modules in Portico after completing pre‑enrolment, and finish module registration by 11 October 2024.

- Complete pre‑enrolment, then open the Module Selection task in Portico.
- Choose your Term 1 and 2 modules, submit, and track approval in My Modules (you’ll be emailed when approved/declined).
- If a selection is declined, choose an alternative from your programme diet (subject to requisites and approval).
- For issues, contact your Programme Administrator; for module-specific advice (syllabus/prereqs), contact the Module Leader via the UCL Module Catalogue.

Warning: Changes to selections must be requested via your home department and need Programme Director and Module Leader approval; change deadlines appear in the Module Selection task on Portico.

Source: Choosing modules for 2024-25; Module selection | UCL Students; Department and faculty-level events and key dates
retrieved_contexts:
Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL  
Module registration for affiliates | UCL Students  
Module selection  
Choosing modules for 2024-25  
Students needing to select optional or elective modules, will be able to do so from before the start of the academic year. New students can register for modules once they have completed pre-enrolment. Continuing students can register for modules once they have completed re-enrolment.  
Students must complete module registration by no later than 11 October 2024, however they are strongly encouraged to complete the process as early as possible.  
Module selection | UCL Students  
Approval of selections  
Students can check the approval status of their module selections in the 'My Modules' area on Portico. Decisions will be notified by email when selections are either approved or declined. Where a selection is rejected, students will be informed of the reason for this and asked to select an appropriate alternative module from the programme diet, subject to the usual requisite conditions and approval process.  
Change of selections  
Students wishing to change a module selection, must make a request to their home department in the first instance. Any change will be subject to the same requisites, orders of priority, and restrictions as an initial selection and must be approved by the Programme Director and the Module Leader.  
Exact deadlines for making changes to module selections will be published each year in the 'Module Selection Task' on Portico.  
Verification of selections

Department and faculty-level events and key dates  
Changes to registration status  
Dates for Study Abroad Year requests and applications are provisional.

Students on Tier 4 Week 49 30 July 2025, 5pm

Academic advice on specific modules  
For advice about a specific module, for example relating to its syllabus, learning outcomes, prerequisite conditions, or self-assessment of suitability, students should contact the Module Leader or general contact, whose contact details are set out in the UCL Module Catalogue.  
Administrative advice and troubleshooting  
If a student experiences any issues with making or confirming their module selections, they should contact their Programme Administrator.

Document (and link to more information) Descriptor Medium How to acquire/ request Eligibility Notes Statement of student status An official letter that can used as proof of enrolment at UCL. Confirms enrolment status, mode of attendance, programme of study, programme start date and programme end date. Digital Access directly via Portico. Available to current students who are enrolled, without debt, and alumni within 2 years of graduation. Statement of student status An official letter that can used as proof of enrolment at UCL. Confirms enrolment status, mode of attendance, programme of study, programme start date and programme end date. Hard copy Request via askUCL : select 'Log an Enquiry' and chose 'proof of student status' from the category section. Available to current students who are enrolled, without debt, and alumni within 2 years of graduation. Record of confirmed module results A Portico record of confirmed module results (marks and grades.) Digital Access directly via Portico following release of confirmed results by UCL Academic Services. Available to students with confirmed module results, including affiliates. Confirmed module results will be released via Portico by UCL Academic Services for each assessment period. Main period 1 (taught modules & undergraduate project/ dissertation modules): mid July 2025. Late summer assessment period: early October 2025. Main period 2 (postgraduate taught project/ dissertation modules): December 2025. Release of a student's results may be delayed where they have approved extensions or submit work late (i.e., which delays marking), or academic misconduct proceedings. Interim transcript An unofficial letter that includes confirmed module results and any recommended or conferred award and any classification. Digital
reference: New undergraduate students at UCL can register for modules once they have completed pre-enrolment. Module registration must be completed by no later than 11 October 2024, although students are strongly encouraged to complete the process as early as possible.

user_input: Could you explain the process and key considerations involved in module selection for a new undergraduate student?
response:
You select your compulsory and any optional/elective modules on Portico after pre‑enrolment, using the Module Catalogue to choose and then obtaining departmental approval.
- Complete pre‑enrolment, then register modules on Portico; finish by 11 October 2024 (earlier is strongly encouraged).
- Review your programme diet and module syllabuses in the UCL Module Catalogue (check pre‑requisites, combinations/mutual exclusions); note module caps may limit places; some CS modules have intro videos.
- Track approval in Portico’s My Modules; you’ll be emailed when selections are approved/declined; if declined, select an alternative from your programme diet.
- To change selections, request via your home department; changes need Programme Director and Module Leader approval; check the Module Selection Task on Portico for change deadlines.
- After approvals/changes, verify your final selections so your record, assessments, and credit volume/level match programme rules.

Source: Module selection | UCL Students
retrieved_contexts:
Exact deadlines for making changes to module selections will be published each year in the 'Module Selection Task' on Portico.  
Verification of selections  
Once the module selection process has been completed, students will be asked to check and confirm their final module selections, after any changes they have requested, are complete and correct. This is an important step that helps us ensure the students academic record is aligned with their studies, that we enter the student for the correct assessments, and that the level and volume of credit selected is appropriate for their programme of study (and its award requirements.)  
Choosing modules for 2025-26 (continuing students)  
Continuing undergraduate students and postgraduate students on programmes of more than 1 year's duration will have an opportunity to make an initial selection of modules for 2025/26 at the end of the spring term, with places being confirmed in the summer.  
Portico | UCL  
Section 2: Module Selection | UCL Academic Manual  
Continuing Student Module Registration | UCL Students  
Availability and allocation of places  
Each module/ module delivery has a fixed upper limit on the number of places available (known as the 'module cap'), based on the department's teaching capacity and other resource constraints.

Students who have previously passed a module that is compulsory during a subsequent period of study (for example, if they took a module as an option on a BSc that is then compulsory on an MSc), then they must discuss this with their Programme Director in advance of module selection and agree a course of action.  
Section 2: Module Selection | UCL Academic Manual

Information about module syllabuses (i.e. their content, learning outcomes, and assessments) and timetabling of synchronous activity.  
A module's syllabus is a summary description of its academic content and how students' learning will be assessed. The syllabus may also include indicative learning outcomes, which describe what skills and knowledge students should be able to demonstrate on successful completion of the module. Students should review the syllabuses for their modules to help them make any optional and elective choices and to help contextualise their learning experience.

Students can access current module syllabuses via the UCL Module Catalogue, which is a comprehensive directory of all modules across the whole of UCL, published in a consistent, searchable and accessible format. The content of syllabuses will vary across departments, but the catalogue aims to give students enough detail to make an informed decision about their module selections. Some Computer Science modules have published module introduction videos to help inform module selection.

Advice on choosing options and electives, general information on choosing modules, and key contacts for module selection.  
Modules  
Modules are the individual units of study which lead to the award of credit (usually 15 or 30 credits for taught modules, 30 credits for undergraduate dissertations/ final projects, 60 credits for postgraduate taught dissertations, and 105 credits for postgraduate research dissertations.) Each degree programme has a programme diet that defines the set of modules that must be taken (referred to compulsory or core), and, in some cases, that may optionally be taken (referred to as optional or elective.)  
Compulsory modules are essential to a programme's core curriculum; optional modules are usually closely related to the programme's core discipline and provide students with an opportunity to specialise in specialist/ complimentary subject areas; elective modules are usually less closely related to the core discipline, but allow students the opportunity to explore their interests more widely.  
Some programmes or years of study do not include optional or elective modules, with all modules being compulsory. Where programmes do include optional or elective choices, these are usually organised into groups which have rules set to define how many credits must or may be taken, whether any selections must be taken in combination or are mutually exclusive, and whether modules have pre-requisite conditions or entry tests.  
Module availability  
Modules for Computer Science students

Computer Science | Study Abroad at UCL  
Module registration for affiliates | UCL Students  
Module selection  
Choosing modules for 2024-25  
Students needing to select optional or elective modules, will be able to do so from before the start of the academic year. New students can register for modules once they have completed pre-enrolment. Continuing students can register for modules once they have completed re-enrolment.  
Students must complete module registration by no later than 11 October 2024, however they are strongly encouraged to complete the process as early as possible.  
Module selection | UCL Students  
Approval of selections  
Students can check the approval status of their module selections in the 'My Modules' area on Portico. Decisions will be notified by email when selections are either approved or declined. Where a selection is rejected, students will be informed of the reason for this and asked to select an appropriate alternative module from the programme diet, subject to the usual requisite conditions and approval process.  
Change of selections  
Students wishing to change a module selection, must make a request to their home department in the first instance. Any change will be subject to the same requisites, orders of priority, and restrictions as an initial selection and must be approved by the Programme Director and the Module Leader.  
Exact deadlines for making changes to module selections will be published each year in the 'Module Selection Task' on Portico.  
Verification of selections
reference: Module selection involves choosing individual units of study called modules, which contribute credits towards a degree. Modules can be compulsory, optional, or elective, with compulsory modules being essential to the core curriculum. Optional modules relate closely to the core discipline and allow some specialisation, while elective modules let students explore broader interests. The programme diet defines which modules must or may be taken. Students must register for modules after completing pre-enrolment and before the deadline of 11 October 2024, though early registration is encouraged. Approval of module selections is managed through the 'My Modules' area on Portico, with notifications sent by email. If a selection is rejected, students must choose an alternative module from the programme diet. Changes to module selections require approval from the home department, Programme Director, and Module Leader, and must meet the same conditions as initial selections. Finally, students must verify their final module selections to ensure their academic record is accurate and aligned with their programme requirements.
